name: Hooked: The Chemical Basis of Drug Addiction
base_name: Hooked: The Chemical Basis of Drug Addiction

anti_reqs.name: Hooked: The Molecular Basis of Addiction

long_desc: What makes us need something so much that it eclipses other important aspects of our lives, such as family, friends, work, hobbies, health and wellness There are many different types of addiction this course will focus on molecular addictions, specifically those involving members of the opiate class of narcotics. The ongoing epidemic of opiate addiction, arising both from overprescription of pain killers and recreational use of heroin, has been widely reported and continues to rise at alarming rates, ravaging our urban and rural communities. In this course, we will explore the complicated role of chemistry in this epidemic, including the good elucidating mechanisms of action, development of clinically useful and safe opiates and nonopiate pain killers and the bad design and synthesis of increasingly addictive opiates. We will also discuss ethical questions faced by the pharmaceutical industry that develops, markets and sells opiates, the medical community that prescribes opiates, and the government agencies charged with regulating these activities. Students who complete this course will emerge with a broad understanding and perspective on an issue that is of great scientific and societal importance. 3 hrs. lec.

custom_fields.goals: Upon completion of this course, students shouldBe familiar with endogenous opioid peptides and other neurotransmitters, how they interact with specific receptor proteins in the brain, and what biological effects these interactions have.Recognize the core structural features of addictive substances that contribute to their biological function.Understand the differences between agonists and antagonists.Recognize how metabolism and biodistribution affect the addictive potential of drugs.Be able to discuss the roles of the pharmaceutical industry, medical professionals and government agencies in the in the regulation, marketing and distribution of both legal and illegal addictive substances.
custom_fields.key_topics: The course provides a holistic view of addiction to opiates and other substances. Scientific topics will include medicinal chemistry, receptor biochemistry and pharmacology, while broader sociological, political and bureaucratic topics will include the role of ethics, regulation (FDA), law enforcement (DEA), Congressional oversight, health care, and journalism in creating, reporting and treating addiction.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will be evaluated based on three types of assignments: (1) 3 homework assignments relating to the material covered in class, (2) A midterm take-home exam that will test the students' overall knowledge and (3) a capstone project in which the goal is to distribute $10,000,000,000 to address the opiate addiction epidemic. These assignments will each be worth 1/3 of the grade.
custom_fields.relevance: The explosion in substance use disorders, particularly involving opiates, is one of the defining social issues of our time, particularly here in the Ohio River valley. Understanding the chemistry and biochemistry of opiates and other addictive substances provides a scientific foundation for appreciating the molecular basis for these diseases, while discussing the broader societal forces that contribute to the societal and economic burdens will hopefully allow students to develop an informed, thoughtful and empathetic perspective on a problem that is impacting all facets of our community.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Instructor's notes, readings, podcasts and documentaries will provide source material for the lectures. The instructor will also hold two office hours per week and will be available by appointment. Students should also purchase three books: (1) Dreamland by Sam Quinones, (2) Never Enough by Dr. Judith Grisel, and (3) American Overdose by Chris McGreal.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students can expect to spend 5-6 hours per week (outside of class) reading course materials and working on assignments. The workload will be fairly consistent, although the capstone project will begin approximately halfway through the semester and will require significantly more work than the other assignments (ca. 10-15 hours versus 2-3 hours).
